snippet: In Emily Bergl’s new show, “NY I Love You,” at the Café Carlyle, she uses the past to illuminate the present and ruthlessly deconstruct sentimental clichés.
abstract: Stephen Holden reviews performance by Emily Bergl in her cabaret show NY I Love You, at the Cafe Carlyle. Photo (M)8
lead_paragraph: Emily Bergl is the very model of a modern gal in too much of a hurry to play by the rules and waste her energy making nice for the sake of good manners. At any time of the day you can see variations of her stage character clacking noisily along Manhattan sidewalks, oblivious to her surroundings, a cellphone glued to her ear. If she's pushing a stroller, you'd better get out of the way. At last week's opening-night performance of her saucy new show, ''NY I Love You,'' in the Café Carlyle, Ms. Bergl strutted to the stage in white tie and tails and fishnet stockings. Her insinuating gaze flashed the mischief and challenge of a woman signaling that she might be too hot to handle. That image was matched be her sassy, tough-cookie voice, a theatrically savvy variation on the assertive whine of today's one-name pop divas. She was accompanied by a quartet led by her pianist, Jonathan Mastro.
